title: Paella Valenciana
ingredients: 1 cup Lima beans or butter beans
steps: Steep saffron threads in 1/4 cup warm stock for 10 minutes to release color and flavor. Set aside.

Heat olive oil in a large paella pan (or wide, shallow pan) over medium-high heat. Season chicken and rabbit pieces with salt. Brown them for 5-6 minutes until golden on all sides. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add green beans and lima beans. Sauté for 3-4 minutes until slightly softened. Remove and set aside with the meat.

Add minced garlic to the pan and sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant. Add grated tomatoes, sweet paprika, and smoked paprika. Cook for 5 minutes, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens and darkens.
Return the meat to the pan. Add the rice and stir for 2 minutes to coat each grain with the tomato mixture and oil. This toasting step is crucial for proper texture.
Pour in the hot chicken stock and saffron with its soaking liquid. Add the rosemary sprig. Stir once to distribute everything evenly, then DO NOT STIR AGAIN - this is essential for authentic paella.
Arrange the green beans and lima beans on top in a decorative pattern. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium-low. Cook uncovered for 18-20 minutes without stirring.

After 15 minutes, check if the rice is tender and the liquid is absorbed. If the rice needs more time but liquid is gone, sprinkle a little hot water around the edges. In the last 2-3 minutes, increase heat to high to create the socarrat (crispy bottom layer) - you should hear crackling sounds.

Remove from heat and cover with a clean kitchen towel. Let rest for 5 minutes. The rice should be tender, slightly al dente, with a golden crispy bottom. Serve directly from the pan with lemon wedges. Authentic paella is eaten with wooden spoons!

title: Gazpacho (Cold Tomato Soup)
ingredients: 1 Red bell pepper, seeded and chopped
1 Green bell pepper, seeded and chopped
For garnish: Diced cucumber, bell pepper, croutons, hard-boiled egg
steps: Soak the bread slice in water for 5 minutes until softened. Squeeze out excess water.
In a blender or food processor, combine tomatoes, cucumber, red and green bell peppers, garlic, and soaked bread. Blend on high speed for 2-3 minutes until completely smooth.

With the blender running, slowly drizzle in the olive oil in a steady stream. This emulsifies the soup and creates a silky texture. Add sherry vinegar, salt, and cumin if using. Blend for another minute.
Taste and adjust seasoning. Gazpacho should be well-balanced - tangy from vinegar, rich from olive oil, and fresh from vegetables.
Strain the soup through a fine-mesh sieve for an ultra-smooth texture (traditional), or leave it slightly chunky if preferred. Press on the solids to extract all liquid.
Transfer to a container and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, preferably 4 hours or overnight. Gazpacho must be served very cold.
Before serving, stir well and check seasoning again - cold temperatures can mute flavors, so you may need to add more salt or vinegar.

Serve in chilled bowls or glasses. Add an ice cube to each serving if desired. Garnish with finely diced cucumber, bell peppers, croutons, and chopped hard-boiled egg. Drizzle with extra virgin olive oil. Gazpacho should be refreshing, vibrant, and perfect for hot summer days.

title: Patatas Bravas (Spicy Potatoes)
ingredients: 800g Potatoes, peeled and cut into 2cm cubes
For Bravas sauce: 2 tbsp Olive oil
steps: Make the bravas sauce: Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Add finely chopped onion and cook for 5-7 minutes until soft and translucent. Add minced garlic and cook for 1 minute.
Add crushed tomatoes, sweet paprika, hot paprika, sugar, and salt. Simmer for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until thickened. Blend until smooth if you prefer, or leave chunky. Set aside.

Make the aioli: In a food processor or with a mortar and pestle, crush garlic with a pinch of salt to a paste. Add egg yolk and blend. Very slowly drizzle in olive oil while blending continuously - start with drops, then a thin stream. The mixture will emulsify and thicken. Add lemon juice and blend. Refrigerate until needed.
Rinse potato cubes in cold water to remove excess starch. Pat completely dry with paper towels - this is crucial for crispy potatoes.
Heat 2-3 inches of oil in a deep pot or fryer to 160°C (320°F). Fry potatoes in batches for 8-10 minutes until tender but not colored. Remove and drain on paper towels. Let cool for 10 minutes.

Increase oil temperature to 190°C (375°F). Fry the potatoes again in batches for 3-4 minutes until golden brown and crispy. This double-frying technique ensures crispy exterior and fluffy interior. Drain and season immediately with salt.
Arrange crispy potatoes on a serving plate. Drizzle generously with warm bravas sauce. Add dollops of aioli on top or serve on the side.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy. Patatas bravas should have crispy golden potatoes with spicy tomato sauce and creamy garlic aioli. Perfect tapas!

title: Churros con Chocolate
ingredients: 1/2 cup Sugar mixed with 1 tsp cinnamon
steps: Make the chocolate sauce: Mix cornstarch with 2 tablespoons of the milk until smooth. Heat remaining milk with sugar in a saucepan over medium heat until steaming. Add chopped chocolate and whisk until melted and smooth.
Add the cornstarch mixture and whisk constantly for 2-3 minutes until the chocolate thickens to a pudding-like consistency. Keep warm on very low heat, stirring occasionally.
Make churro dough: In a medium saucepan, combine water, 2 tablespoons sugar, salt, and butter. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring until butter melts.
Remove from heat and immediately add all the flour at once. Stir vigorously with a wooden spoon until the mixture forms a smooth ball and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Let cool for 5 minutes. Add the egg and vanilla extract. Beat vigorously until fully incorporated and the dough is smooth and glossy. The dough should be thick but pipeable.
Transfer dough to a piping bag fitted with a large star tip (this creates the signature ridges).

Heat 2-3 inches of oil in a deep pot to 190°C (375°F). Pipe 4-5 inch strips of dough directly into the hot oil, using scissors to cut. Fry 3-4 churros at a time for 2-3 minutes per side until deep golden brown and crispy.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels for 30 seconds. While still hot, roll in cinnamon sugar to coat completely.

Serve churros immediately while hot and crispy with the warm thick chocolate sauce for dipping. Spanish churros are typically thicker than Mexican ones and the chocolate should be very thick - almost like pudding. Perfect for breakfast or afternoon merienda!

title: Sangria (Spanish Wine Punch)
ingredients: 1 bottle (750ml) Spanish red wine (Rioja or Tempranillo)
2 tbsp Orange liqueur (Cointreau or Triple Sec)
1 cup Sparkling water or lemon soda
steps: In a large pitcher, combine the red wine, brandy, and orange liqueur. Stir well.
Add sugar and stir until completely dissolved. The amount of sugar can be adjusted based on the sweetness of your wine and personal preference.
Add sliced orange, lemon, lime, diced apple, fresh berries, and cinnamon stick to the pitcher. Gently muddle the fruit slightly with a wooden spoon to release some juices, but don't mash completely.
Pour in the orange juice and stir everything together.
Cover the pitcher and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight. This allows the flavors to meld and the fruit to infuse the wine. The longer it sits, the better it tastes.
Just before serving, add the sparkling water or lemon soda for fizz. Stir gently.
Fill glasses with ice cubes. Pour sangria over ice, making sure each glass gets some of the fruit.
Serve immediately. Sangria should be fruity, refreshing, and not too sweet. The fruit pieces are meant to be eaten! Perfect for summer gatherings and fiestas. ¡Salud!
